title: Question 91

children: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for 3-month history of mildly pruritic rash on her feet, with thickening and discoloration of several toenails. She states that she is not concerned about the toenails because polish covers them. She has no other medical problems.
Skin findings are
shown
Upon removing the toenail polish, several nails are dystrophic, with subungual keratosis and discoloration.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's rash?

The chronic form of tinea pedis presents as mildly pruritic scaly patches involving most of the soles in a “moccasin” distribution; the interdigital variant of tinea pedis shows fissures and maceration in the folds.
Recommended treatment of localized tinea on non–hair-bearing skin is terbinafine or imidazole creams, such as miconazole, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient's rash is terbinafine cream (
Option E

). This patient has tinea pedis. The chronic form of tinea pedis presents as mildly pruritic scaly patches involving most of the soles in a “moccasin” distribution. “Two feet-one hand” tinea is a characteristic pattern of involvement. Tinea pedis can have a more acute form, with 1- to 2-mm vesicles, and can be extremely pruritic. The interdigital variant of tinea pedis shows fissures and maceration in the folds (as
shown

This patient's plaques with serpiginous and arcuate scaly borders in a moccasin distribution should raise suspicion for dermatophyte infection. Tinea should be treated to prevent skin breakdown, which can be an entry port for bacterial infection. Dermatophytosis of non–hair-bearing skin with limited involvement can be treated topically with the use of topical terbinafine or imidazole creams, such as miconazole, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole, applied once to twice daily for 2 to 4 weeks, ensuring that the application extends a few centimeters beyond the advancing border. Combined antifungals and topical glucocorticoids should be avoided because they can lead to increased recurrences and treatment failures.
Adalimumab (
Option A
) and clobetasol (
Option B

) are not helpful in the treatment of dermatophytosis but are effective in the treatment of psoriasis, which can affect the soles of the feet and nails. Psoriasis appears as discrete, sharply marginated red plaques with silvery lamellar scale. The arcuate and serpiginous scale and the dull brown-red color of this patient's skin findings are not consistent with the presentation of psoriasis.
Topical nystatin cream (
Option C
) is beneficial in the treatment of cutaneous candidiasis, but it is not effective in the treatment of dermatophyte infections, such as tinea pedis.
Although systemic antifungal agents, such as itraconazole (
Option D

), can be beneficial in the treatment of onychomycosis, this patient reports she is not concerned with treating her toenails. Furthermore, itraconazole is rarely used for the treatment of onychomycosis due to its side effect profile. Systemic terbinafine or fluconazole are more commonly utilized.

references: Aizenberg DJ. Common complaints of the hands and feet. Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:187-97.
